segment.source: Exercise 4 - Use MXA to Analyze Audio Glitches
segment.target: Exercise 4 - Use MXA to Analyze Audio Glitches

segment.source: In this lab, you’ll analyze audio glitches.
segment.target: In this lab, you’ll analyze audio glitches.

segment.source: Exercise 4 - Use MXA to Analyze Audio Glitches
segment.target: Exercise 4 - Use MXA to Analyze Audio Glitches

segment.source: In this lab, you’ll analyze audio glitches.
segment.target: In this lab, you’ll analyze audio glitches.

segment.source: Audio glitches are often caused by one of the following issues:
segment.target: Audio glitches are often caused by one of the following issues:

segment.source: A Deferred Procedure Call (DPC) or an Interrupt Service Routine (ISR) that runs longer than 1 millisecond.
segment.target: A Deferred Procedure Call (DPC) or an Interrupt Service Routine (ISR) that runs longer than 1 millisecond.

segment.source: A driver or kernel thread that runs at dispatch level for 1 millisecond or longer.
segment.target: A driver or kernel thread that runs at dispatch level for 1 millisecond or longer.

segment.source: Data cannot be read from the disk or the network isn’t fast enough because of high disk or network utilization.
segment.target: Data cannot be read from the disk or the network isn’t fast enough because of high disk or network utilization.

segment.source: The hardware or software decoder cannot decode and process the stream faster than real-time.
segment.target: The hardware or software decoder cannot decode and process the stream faster than real-time.

segment.source: Step 1: Open the trace in MXA and drag the pertinent datasets into panels
segment.target: Step 1: Open the trace in MXA and drag the pertinent datasets into panels

segment.source: Install Media eXperience Analyzer (MXA) which can be downloaded here.
segment.target: Install Media eXperience Analyzer (MXA) which can be downloaded here.

segment.source: Right-click on the Start menu and click on Command Prompt (Admin).
segment.target: Right-click on the Start menu and click on Command Prompt (Admin).

segment.source: Navigate to the folder where you installed MXA.
segment.target: Navigate to the folder where you installed MXA.

segment.source: Set the MXA symbol paths on your PC.
segment.target: Set the MXA symbol paths on your PC.

segment.source: Download AudioGlitchesThreadsAtDispatchLevel.etl from here.
segment.target: Download AudioGlitchesThreadsAtDispatchLevel.etl from here.

segment.source: Open the AudioGlitchesThreadsAtDispatchLevel.etl trace file by typing the following command:
segment.target: Open the AudioGlitchesThreadsAtDispatchLevel.etl trace file by typing the following command:

segment.source: For example, if you downloaded AudioGlitchesThreadsAtDispatchLevel.etl to C:PerformanceMedia, you would type the following command:
segment.target: For example, if you downloaded AudioGlitchesThreadsAtDispatchLevel.etl to C:PerformanceMedia, you would type the following command:

segment.source: On the MXA splash screen, press the Turn Symbols Off button to turn off symbol lookup.
segment.target: On the MXA splash screen, press the Turn Symbols Off button to turn off symbol lookup.

segment.source: Once the trace is loaded, close any open panels that appear in the center of the application by pressing the small X next to the name of each panel.
segment.target: Once the trace is loaded, close any open panels that appear in the center of the application by pressing the small X next to the name of each panel.

segment.source: Add 3 new panels.
segment.target: Add 3 new panels.

segment.source: Click ViewNew Panel or press CTRL+N.
segment.target: Click ViewNew Panel or press CTRL+N.

segment.source: Drag and drop the Audio Glitches Classic dataset under the Media node into the top panel.
segment.target: Drag and drop the Audio Glitches Classic dataset under the Media node into the top panel.

segment.source: Drag and drop the Scheduler dataset under the CPU node into the 2nd panel from the top.
segment.target: Drag and drop the Scheduler dataset under the CPU node into the 2nd panel from the top.

segment.source: Drag and drop the Sampled Profiles dataset under the CPU node into the 3rd panel from the top.
segment.target: Drag and drop the Sampled Profiles dataset under the CPU node into the 3rd panel from the top.

segment.source: Filter the idle processes out of the view so that you can see the other thread activity more clearly.
segment.target: Filter the idle processes out of the view so that you can see the other thread activity more clearly.

segment.source: In the dataset tree, expand the Scheduler dataset in the CPU node and click the Idle Threads node checkbox twice to deselect it.
segment.target: In the dataset tree, expand the Scheduler dataset in the CPU node and click the Idle Threads node checkbox twice to deselect it.

segment.source: Clicking the checkbox once highlights the data in the graph; clicking it twice deselects it.
segment.target: Clicking the checkbox once highlights the data in the graph; clicking it twice deselects it.

segment.source: Step 2: Identify the region of the trace where an audio glitch occurred
segment.target: Step 2: Identify the region of the trace where an audio glitch occurred

segment.source: You can look at the audio engine data from the event trace log (.etl) files to see a visual timeline of when these glitches occurred and compare the timeline to other sets of data to look for patterns.
segment.target: You can look at the audio engine data from the event trace log (.etl) files to see a visual timeline of when these glitches occurred and compare the timeline to other sets of data to look for patterns.

segment.source: Zoom in on an audio glitch by clicking and dragging the mouse over one of the bars in the Audio Glitches Classic panel at the top.
segment.target: Zoom in on an audio glitch by clicking and dragging the mouse over one of the bars in the Audio Glitches Classic panel at the top.

segment.source: Notice that the iexplore.exe process in the Scheduler dataset in the 2nd panel was running for a long time (~20-35ms) just before the audio glitch.
segment.target: Notice that the iexplore.exe process in the Scheduler dataset in the 2nd panel was running for a long time (~20-35ms) just before the audio glitch.

segment.source: Press escape to zoom out 100% then repeat the previous two steps to verify the pattern where the iexplore.exe process was running for long durations (~20-35 ms) prior to every audio glitch.
segment.target: Press escape to zoom out 100% then repeat the previous two steps to verify the pattern where the iexplore.exe process was running for long durations (~20-35 ms) prior to every audio glitch.

segment.source: To measure time within the panel, press the SHIFT key while you drag your mouse from one end of the iexplore.exe process bar to the other.
segment.target: To measure time within the panel, press the SHIFT key while you drag your mouse from one end of the iexplore.exe process bar to the other.

segment.source: The tooltip over the mouse cursor shows you how many milliseconds you are measuring on the timeline.
segment.target: The tooltip over the mouse cursor shows you how many milliseconds you are measuring on the timeline.

segment.source: In the MXA screenshot below, the process was running for about 35 milliseconds.
segment.target: In the MXA screenshot below, the process was running for about 35 milliseconds.

segment.source: Step 3: Identify the cause of the delays in the pipeline
segment.target: Step 3: Identify the cause of the delays in the pipeline

segment.source: Before this audio glitch, the long-running iexplore.exe process was running on one of the cores.
segment.target: Before this audio glitch, the long-running iexplore.exe process was running on one of the cores.

segment.source: To find out how the iexplore.exe thread is stalling the audio pipeline, you can look at the corresponding Sampled Profiles dataset in the CPU node.
segment.target: To find out how the iexplore.exe thread is stalling the audio pipeline, you can look at the corresponding Sampled Profiles dataset in the CPU node.

segment.source: If the CallStack dataviewer is not visible in the MXA window, click ViewData ViewersCallStack to open it.
segment.target: If the CallStack dataviewer is not visible in the MXA window, click ViewData ViewersCallStack to open it.

segment.source: In the Sampled Profiles panel (3rd from the top), hover over the sample profile events that match the same color of the long running iexplore.exe thread.
segment.target: In the Sampled Profiles panel (3rd from the top), hover over the sample profile events that match the same color of the long running iexplore.exe thread.

segment.source: The CallStack window shows the callstack for each sample.
segment.target: The CallStack window shows the callstack for each sample.

segment.source: Notice that a specific driver, ImageRAMONA.sys, is at the top of the CallStack when you hover over most of the samples in the core that iexplore.exe is running on.
segment.target: Notice that a specific driver, ImageRAMONA.sys, is at the top of the CallStack when you hover over most of the samples in the core that iexplore.exe is running on.

segment.source: Although the audiodg.exe thread is running at a higher priority (priority 22) than the iexplore.exe thread (priority 19), the iexplore.exe thread calls into a driver (ImageRAMONA.sys), which raises the IRQL level of the processor.
segment.target: Although the audiodg.exe thread is running at a higher priority (priority 22) than the iexplore.exe thread (priority 19), the iexplore.exe thread calls into a driver (ImageRAMONA.sys), which raises the IRQL level of the processor.

segment.source: As a result, audiodg.exe, which is waiting on a DPC retained by the dispatcher doesn’t have a chance to run on its regular 10ms cadence, resulting in audio glitches.
segment.target: As a result, audiodg.exe, which is waiting on a DPC retained by the dispatcher doesn’t have a chance to run on its regular 10ms cadence, resulting in audio glitches.

segment.source: Hold down the SHIFT key to freeze the CallStack and Properties Data Viewers and move your mouse to the CallStack.
segment.target: Hold down the SHIFT key to freeze the CallStack and Properties Data Viewers and move your mouse to the CallStack.

segment.source: Press Copy.
segment.target: Press Copy.
